[@Nick Redmark](@zEbr4oS0j1O41UYGBVbay+4NvAc2yfJi43yW3Yx28BI=.ed25519) 

I don't think my perspective is representative of the rest of the rest of the community, but I'm super down for being explicit (verbose?) about the semantics of our messages. I've wanted to try JSON-LD for this sort of thing, which accomplishes the above with:

```json
{
  "@context": "https://example.com/nmaro/ssb-projects/v1",
  "@type": "task",
  "foo": "bar"
}
```

With that said: try out whatever you'd like! I don't think there's been much experimentation with schema versioning, so we haven't settled on any best practices yet. Lots more info and opinions in this thread: %qTEUjQajo0VCc6RkoCBdG/Klqo1LKCsHfaK+RQP0kdI=.sha256

Another approach would be to use an existing RDF schema published somewhere else. For example, a task could be described by a schema.org [Action](https://schema.org/Action), so you'd have:

```json
{
  "@context": "http://schema.org/version/2.0/",
  "@type": "Action",
  "agent": "ssb:feed:ed25519:zEbr4oS0j1O41UYGBVbay-4NvAc2yfJi43yW3Yx28BI=",
  "actionStatus": "CompletedActionStatus",
  "object": "https://example.com/some/task"
}
```

The trade-off is that you get well-specified data types but your messages become super verbose and enterprisey. I don't know if the trade-off is worth it, but it's an option. ðŸ¤· Happy to discuss further, but feel free to experiment.
